Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Spatial Ecology and Evolution: Quantitative Training in Biology, Statistics, and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the interdisciplinary training of doctoral students in ecology and evolution, mathematics and statistics in order to address research questions that have an important spatial dimension. Most environmental issues are inherently spatial: for example, emerging pathogens and invasive species appear in one place and disperse to others; toxicants released from many point sources create a mosaic of exposure regimes; populations respond to environmental change by evolving and migrating. Understanding ecological systems in a spatial context provides deeper understanding and helps to predict and manage environmental change of all kinds, but it requires both new biological ideas and new quantitative tools. Thus in this award trainees will learn to cross the boundaries between biology, statistics, and mathematics, and to apply basic knowledge to environmental challenges. After learning common disciplinary concepts, trainees will participate in a novel year-long interdisciplinary workshop to tackle applied spatial problems in ecology and evolution defined by clients from government agencies and non-governmental organizations. The workshops will require students to learn new tools, apply theory to real-world challenges, and disseminate tools and knowledge (to other scientists, to stakeholders, and to non-scientists). A weekly ?spatial dynamics? colloquium will provide cohesion and breadth, and an annual symposium will provide further avenues for learning and communication. Students will be prepared to and given the opportunity to teach interdisciplinary topics in undergraduate and graduate courses throughout the university. The program will also broaden the training of other graduate students in this area, and break down institutional barriers that isolate scientists in their home disciplines. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our IGERT trained  5 cohorts (a total of 25 trainees and 18 associates), who were mentored by 37 faculty members from a number of departments and units across campus. Our trainees and associates published more than 70 journal articles and gave more than 140 conference presentations. Trainees worked on interdisciplinary projects, defined in consultation with external clients. The projects were in two general areas: spatial ecology and infectious disease.  Here we highlight three of those projects.

 

Fisheries Management.  One project (from our fifth cohort) was focused on optimal management strategies and long-term sustainability of the brown shrimp fishery. Shrimp species vary in their reproductive strategies, and because brown shrimp support an economically important fishery in the Unites States, changes in the timing of their reproduction could potentially have significant economic and social consequences. The interdisciplinary IGERT team investigated the effect of the temporal variation in reproductive allocation and effort on the population size of brown shrimp along a latitudinal gradient in the Gulf of Mexico. Trainees found that, as the length of the growing season increased with decreasing latitude, the reproductive strategy leading to the highest population size changed from one annual birth pulse with high reproductive output to continuous low-output reproduction. Hence, their model confirms the classical paradigm of continuous reproduction at low latitudes, with increased seasonality of breeding period towards the poles. Their results also show that latitudinal variation in climate affects which reproductive strategy leads to the largest population size, and thus which management strategy will be most sustainable. The results also indicate that a change in climate could potentially change which reproductive strategy is favored and which management strategy will be most effective.

 

Malaria and social networks in Hispaniola.  Another project (tackled by our second cohort) was concerned with the elimination of malaria in Haiti and the Dominican Republic. The efficacy of different strategies, however, depends on social networks and the resulting patterns of human movement and contacts.  Using cell-phone data provided by one of the clients, and through collaboration across disciplines, the trainees described the pattern of modularity in the communication network in the Dominican Republic. Using these data, the trainees demonstrated that place-based attributes, including sugar cane production, urbanization, distance to the nearest airport, and wealth, correctly predicted community membership for over 70% of mobile phone towers. Analysis determined that place-based attributes can accurately represent the processes driving modularity. In the absence of social network data, the methods the trainees presented can be used to predict community membership over large scales using solely place-based attributes.  In turn, this information can be used to better target strategies aimed at reducing transmission dynamics, containing outbreaks, and eventually, eliminating malaria from the island.
